text: Cross-linking of Fc gamma receptors activates HIV-1 long terminal repeat - driven transcription in human monocytes .
Elevation of the levels of circulating immune complexes frequently accompanies HIV-1 infection and is a prognostic indicator of clinical progression from asymptomatic infection to AIDS .

Here we report that cross-linking of <extra_id_0> Fc gamma RI <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> Fc gamma RII <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by adherent human IgG or by specific anti-Fc gamma R mAb activates HIV-1 gene expression in the human monocytic cell line BF24 and increased HIV RNA expression in monocytes from HIV infected patients as assayed by reverse transcription - PCR .

text: In THP-1 cells , Fc gamma R cross-linking induced NF-kappa B , which is known to bind to the regulatory region of the long terminal repeat ( LTR ) of HIV-1 and to activate HIV-1 transcription .

Anti - <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibody but not anti - <extra_id_0> IL-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibody strongly inhibited both the induction of HIV-1-LTR - driven transcription and the induction of NF-kappa B by Fc gamma R cross-linking .

These results indicate that Fc gamma R can mediate a <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent induction of HIV-1 gene transcription and suggest that immune complexes may contribute to the pathophysiology of HIV-1 infection by augmenting viral replication in monocytes .
